relationships.notes: Married collaborator whose mobility, hospitality, and shared teaching vocation with Aquila anchor their presence from Italy to Ephesus.
Receives Paul into her household, travels with him, and is commended for risking her life in the service of his Gentile mission.
Alongside Aquila, instructs Apollos privately to complete his understanding of the way, demonstrating theological discernment.

traits.part_of_missionary_couple: Appears together with her husband Aquila as part of a married ministry team associated with Paul.
traits.mobility_in_mission: Travels with Aquila from Italy to Corinth and then to Ephesus, reflecting the movement of diaspora Jewish believers in the early mission.
traits.instruction_of_apollos: Alongside Aquila, takes Apollos aside and explains the way of God more accurately, indicating theological competence and teaching authority.
traits.name_order_observation: In some passages, her name precedes Aquila’s, a detail often noted by interpreters as suggesting particular prominence.

traits.coworker_and_risk_taker: Praised with Aquila as coworker of Paul who risked their necks for his life, eliciting thanks from Paul and all the churches of the Gentiles.
traits.house_church_leader: Hosts a church in their house, signaling a role in organizing and sustaining local gatherings.
traits.greeting_priority: Sometimes named before her husband in greeting lists, which some see as highlighting her notable status in the movement.

traits.continued_presence: Mentioned again, together with Aquila, in a later letter, implying ongoing involvement in Christian ministry.
traits.critical_note: This greeting appears in a letter widely regarded by critical scholarship as post-Pauline, preserving the memory of the couple’s significance.
